gurmukhi: bolq hY muK qy sB gÍwrn puMin krXo ienhUM Aiq mweI ]j`gX krY ik krXo qp qIrQ gMDRb qy ien kY isC pweI ]
transliteration: Dolat Hai Moukh Te Sabh Gvaaran Pounn(i) Daryo Inhoon At(i) Maaee|| Jaggya Darai Ki Daryo Tap Teerath Gaddhrab Te In Kai Sichh Paaee||
translation: “O mother! This flute has performed many austerities, abstinences and baths at pilgrim-stations; it has received instructions from Gandharvas;

gurmukhi: kY ik pVI isq bwn hu qy ik ikDo cqurwnn Awp bnweI ]sXwm khY aupmw iqhkI ieh qy hir ETn swQ lgweI ]234]
transliteration: Kai Ki Padi Sit Baan Hu Te Ki Kidho Chaturaanan Aap Banaaee|| Syaam Kahai Oupmaa Tihkieh Te Har(i) Othan Saath Lagadee||234||
translation: “It has been instructed by the god of love and Brahma has made it himself; this is the reason that Krishna has touchéd it with his lips.”234.

gurmukhi: suq nMd bjwvq hY murlI aupmw iqh kI kib sXwm gno ]iqh kI Duin ko suin moih rhy mun rIJq hY su jnoru kno ]
transliteration: Sout Nand Bajaavat Hai Murlioupmaa Tih Kikabi Syaam Gado Tih Kidhoun(i) Ko Soun(i) Moh(i) Rahe Mounndreejhat Hai Su Janor(u) Kano||
translation: Krishna, the son of Nand, is playing on his flute and the poet Shyam says that hearing the sound of the flute, the sages and the beings of the forest are getting pleased;

gurmukhi: qn kwm BrI gupIAw sB hI muK qy iem Bwqn jÍwb Bno ]muK kwnH gulwb ko PUl BXo ieh nwl gulwb cuAwq mno ]235]
transliteration: Tan Kaam Bharigoupiaa Sabh Himoukh Te Im Bhaatan Jvaab Bhano|| Moukh Kaahn Gulaab Ko Phool Bhayo Eh Naal Gulaab Chuaat Mano||235||
translation: The bodies of the gopis have been filled with lust and they are saying that the mouth of Krishna is like a rose and the voice of the flute seems like the essence of the rose dripping down.235.

gurmukhi: moih rhy suin kY Duin ko miRg moih pswr gy K`g pY p`Kw ]nIr bhXo jmnw aulto ipK kY iqh ko nr Kol ry c`Kw ]
transliteration: Moh(i) Rahe Soun(i) Kai Dhoun(i) Ko Mrig Moh(i) Pasaar Ge Khagg Pai Pakhhaa|| Neer Bahyo Jamnaa Ulto Pikh Kai Tih Ko Nar Dhol Re Chakkhaa||
translation: Hearing the voice of the flute, the fish, dear and bird all are infatuated, “O people! Open your eyes and see that the water of Yamuna is flowing in the opposite direction;”

gurmukhi: sXwm khY iqnko suinkY bCrw muK so kCu nw cugY k`Kw ]Coif clI pqnI Apny pq qwrk hÍY ijm fwrq l`Kw ]136]
transliteration: Syaam Kahai Tinko Soun(i)kai Bachhraa Moukh So Kachhu Naa Chougad Kakkhaa|| Chhodh(i) Chalipatni Apne Pat Taarak Hvai Jim Daarat Lakhkhaa||136||
translation: The poet says that hearing the flute, the calves have stopped eating grass; the wife has left her husband like a Sannyasi leaving his home and wealth.236.

gurmukhi: koikl kIr kurMgn ky hir mYn rhXo hÍYkY mqvwro ]rIJ rhy sB hI pur kY jn Awnn pY ieh qy sis hwro ]
transliteration: Kakil Keer Kuranad Ke Har(i) Main Rahyo Hvai-kai Matdaro|| Reejh Rahe Sabh Hipur Kai Jan Aanan Pai Eh Te Sas(i) Daro||
translation: The nightingales, parrots and deer etc., all have been absorbed in the anguish of lust; all the people of the city are getting pleased and saying that the moon seems bedimmed before the face of Krishna;

gurmukhi: Aau ieh kI murlI ju bjY iqh aUpir rwg sBY Puin vwro ]nwrd jwq QkY ieh qy bMsrI ju bjwvq kwnr kwro ]237]
transliteration: Au Eh Kimurliju Bajai Tih Oopar(i) Raag Sabhai Phoun(i) Daro|| Naarad Jaat Thakai Eh Te Bansariju Bajaavat Kaanar Daro||237||
translation: All the musical modes are sacrificing themselves before the tune of the flute; the sage Narad, stopping the playing of his lyre, has been listening to the flute of the black Krishna and has got tired.237.

gurmukhi: locn hY miRg ky kt ky hir nwk ikDo suk ko iqhko hY ]gRIv kpoq sI hY iqh kI ADrw pIA sy hir mUrq jo hY ]
transliteration: Lochanndhai Mrig Ke Kat Ke Har(i) Naak Kidho Souk Ko Tihko Hai|| Greev Kapot Sihai Tih Kiadhraa Peea Se Har(i) Moondat Jo Hai||
translation: His (Krishna’s) eyes are like those of the doe, the waist is like that of the lion, the nose is like that of the parrot, the neck like that of the pigeon and lips (adhar) are like ambrosia;

gurmukhi: koikl Aau ipk sy bcnwmiRq sXwm khY kib suMdr sohY ]pY ieh qy lj kY Ab bolq mUrq lY n kry Kg rohY ]238]
transliteration: Kokil Au Pik Se Bachnaamrit Syaam Kahai Kabi Soundar Sohai|| Pai Ih Te Laj Kai Jab Dolat Moondat Lai Na Dare Khag Rohai||238||
translation: His speech is sweet like the nightingale and the peacock; these sweetly-speaking beings are now feeling shy of the sound of the flute and are getting jealous in their mids.238.

gurmukhi: PUl gulwb n lyq hY qwb shwb ko Awb hÍY dyK iKswno ]pY kmlw dl nrgs ko gul l`jq hY Puin dyKq qwno ]
transliteration: Phool Gulaab Na Let Hai Taab Sahaab Ko Aab Hvai Dekh Khisaano|| Pai Kamlaa Dal Nargad Ko Gul Lajjat Hai Phoun(i) Dekhat Taano||
translation: The rose insipid before his beauty and the red and elegant colour is feeling embarrassed before his comeliness; the lotus and narcissus are feeling shy before his charm;

gurmukhi: sXwm ikDo Apny mn mY br qwgn kY kibqw ieh Twno ]doKn ko ien ky sm pUrb p`Cm folY lhy nih Awno ]239]
transliteration: Syaam Kidho Apne Man Mai Bar Taagad Kai Kabitaa Eh Thaano|| Dekhan Ko In Ke Sam Poorab Pachchham Dolai Lahe Nah(i) Aano||239||
translation: The poet Shyam appears indecisive in his mind about his beauty and says that he has not been able to find a winsome person like Krishna though he has roamed from east to west in order to see one like him.239.

gurmukhi: mMGr mY sB hI gupIAw imil pUjq cMf pqy hir kwjY ]pRwq smy jmnw mD nHwbq dyK iqnY jljM muK lwjY ]
transliteration: Manhar Mai Sabh Higoupeeaa Mil(i) Poojat Channdd Pate Har(i) Kaajai|| Praat Same Jamnaa Madh Nhaavat Dekh Tinai Jaljan Moukh Laajai||
translation: In the month of Maghar all the gopis worship Durga wishing for Krishna as their husband; early in the morning, they take bath in Yamuna and seeing them, the lotus flowers feel shy;
